segments.text: Could we talk a little bit about around 1971, the mechanics involved, what the government did to combine the lines when Amtrak came out into existence?
Yes.
When Amtrak came into existence, the government legislation was prepared to create them.
The railroads that had passenger trains running,
had the option of either continuing to run them themselves and suffer whatever losses or consequences they wanted to suffer, or join Amtrak.
And Amtrak then would contract with them to operate the trains.
And they were taking over equipment
was rapidly reaching the end of its useful lifetime.

And to give you an example of some of the equipment problems they had when this came about, most all the railroads joined Amtrak because they wanted to get out of this money losing mess that they were in.
Only the Southern and the Rio Grande and the, I don't know, the three maybe that go to Florida.
I can't tell you which ones they were, but the Southern Crescent remained the Southern's Crescent, and they ran that passenger train and did not join any of that.
They have now joined the Rio Grande.
got a passenger train that they ran, and now it's into the Anchorage area.
I don't think it's Rock Island.
There were three, I think, all the way from here.
They did this, and all of a sudden, on the Texas Chief, and then was renamed the Lone Star,

We had Santa Fe Concess trains that came in here, all the cars matched, all of them had the same kind of air conditioning, for example, and our low-level cars, they were all steam-actuated air conditioners.
Now, the person that maintained those cars at night, when the train came in and checked out everything, knew that air conditioning system very well.
The high-level cars that the Santa Fe ran were a different air conditioning system, but again, they were all alike.
So there were two air conditioning systems, one for the high-level and one for the low-level.
That's all they had to contend with, and they had spare parts and all that sort of stuff.
All of a sudden, you had trains coming in with cars on them from all kinds of railroad lines.
And I remember one night, the Lone Star came in,
And it had a Waukesha Pierce air conditioner that was out on one car.
But then steam-activated Santa Fe was out on another car.
And this was in the summertime.
And they had a mechanical air conditioning deal that was out on a third one.
Three different kinds of air conditioners.
And no parts stopped.
It was a disaster.

One of the things that has come about in Amtrak that has really revolutionized this thing and really been a turnaround as far as equipment is concerned is that Charlie Luna, who is on the board of directors of Amtrak and is a tech scientist from Dallas, Florida, conceived the idea that we should convert
All of the older equipment is still good enough to operate.
They should convert it all to what he calls head-in power.
So no matter what kind of air conditioning system is on this car, it's going to be removed and it's going to be replaced with electrical heat and air conditioning.
Electricity provided by a big 640 volt generator in the engine.
So you have to train line this electricity back, 640 volt electricity back.
That, of course, costs a lot of money for a car to convert.
But it gives you something that works.
And standardized and works.
And there's this plan and they've done that now so that all the heritage equipment, ones that are inherited from the railroads, have all been converted to head-end power, every one of them.
And all the steam, activated air conditioning, steam heating is all gone.
So it's, and all the new equipment that's heading down, all the new super liners that they produce, the high-level cars, have you been on them?
Have you been here?
Oh, yeah, they're really great.
And they're out of the way expensive, you know.
The sleeping accommodations up in the top are just for something like $20, $25 a night, more than it takes to get there.
And, you know, it's not killing you.
It's not a price that will drive you home.
The Amtrak essentially is... Re-built.
They re-built everything.
They've either got brand new...
Now, over on the east coast, they have to run .
They won't have .
one of the things
that the power that Superlion cars have in contrast to the last few years is one of the things that we need to look at.
And they've got an available dispute and a trial that's been going on for about two years.
And it's pretty clean to believe that Superlion is going on for a long time.
And in the meantime, things are just going downhill.
a lot of a lot of what happened
so much
You said that you're interested in Midwestern swimming and Chinese swimming.
When did that come about?
Yeah, when I started that way, you know, this isn't the only good thing about it.
It's about feeling real good about it.
Have y'all had problems getting the private part to be pulled by one side?
Oh, you've got to tell your daddy on that, so he can go through both on both.
I don't know how I'm going to call it.
One other thing that I think is very important.
I was at one time on the board of directors.
And that was the first time I was on the board of directors meeting.
We were the only job in Canada that served people providing the end vaccine that they were contracted to run.
And we got a reporting of more than one increase of the capacity in New Orleans.
They were dispatching a local freighter.
And I'm sure you all can think of it right.
He dispatched a local freighter towards San Quentin in the U.S.
So that means that San Quentin would be walking around and cutting out stuff and leaving it on the side and putting stuff up.
Working all the way to the end of the day at the perfect time.
Then he dispatched a few more freighters at two feet
which was blocked by the locusts.
So even that was rancid.
Then he dispatched his insects to harm the people.
Then the sunset limited that night to something like nine and a half hours late getting to Houston.
Can you imagine why it was nine and a half hours late?
Well, that was the kind of evidence that was presented to the federal chief by the presentation.
and instead of being
We've been having performances that were 30% on time, and they balled it into the ladies and stuff like that.
Just overnight.
Just overnight.
There was one big lawsuit.
So sometimes I think that's who you are.
You've just got to see somebody in order to get to the point.
and the passenger writing letters to some of these and all that.
It's probably been some other format.
In order to change anything, I don't know, Marvel realizes that it is an impact of a political act that does exactly what the Congress tells it to do.
Dr. Matney, I appreciate you taking the time to look over my outline and for giving me this interview this morning.
Thank you.
